trial_identification.studytitle: The ability of dietary calcium to influence fat oxidation, glucose levels and satiety in caucasian adults.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The role of calcium in the modulation of postprandial substrate oxidation following sequential meals in caucasian human subjects.

interventions.interventions: Randomized, within-subject trial comparing two breakfast-lunch combinations that only differ in calcium content of breakfast (~250mg versus 550mg). Each combination will be adminstered on one occassion only, in a random order. Volunteers will crossover to the second combination following a 2 week washout period. Breakfast will consist of rolled oats, sultanas, cream, milk and sugar while lunch will consist of a white bread sandwich of ham, tomato, butter with a serving of fruit and fruit juice.
interventions.comparator: The low calcium (~250mg) breakfast-standard lunch combination is the comparator treatment. Each breakfast-lunch combination will be adminstered on one occassion only, in a random order, and volunteers will crossover to the alternative combination following a 2 week washout period.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Whole body fat oxidation based on indirect calorimetry
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and every 30 minutes for 8 hours following consumption of breakfast meal.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: subjective hunger/satiety ratings using 10 cm visual analogue scales.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and every 30 minutes for 8 hours following consumption of breakfast meal.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: insulin and glucose responses from venous blood samples
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and every 30 minutes for 8 hours following consumption of breakfast meal.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Reported food intake using a food diary
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: A buffet meal will be served 4 hr after lunch and will consist of a choice of bread, pumpkin soup, cheese, carrot sticks, crackers, almonds, apricots, baked apple bar, fruit in juice, milk chocolate, orange juice, tea and coffee. Volunteers will record their food intake for 30h after the buffet.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Caucasian adults, body mass index >20 kg/m2, weight stable over last 6 months, < 2 alcoholic drinks per day.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: lactose intolerance or gastrointestinal disturbances, hormone replacement therapy, medications for systemic diseases or vitamin/mineral supplements

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of this study is to examine whether a change in calcium intake at one meal modifies the way in which we handle the subsequent meal. We believe that increasing calcium intake at breakfast improves the body's ability to handle glucose following lunch, while promoting utilization of fat and suppressing subjective ratings of hunger.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: M J Soares and W Chan She Ping-Delfos. Second meal effects of dietary calcium and vitamin D. European Journal of Clinical Nutrition (2008) 62, 872878; doi:10.1038/sj.ejcn.1602803; published online 23 May 2007.
